introduction.text: Elinor is a free and open-source monitoring tool that helps users gather, store, share, and use data on environmental governance and management to support more effective area-based conservation.

explanation.title: WHY SHOULD I USE IT?
explanation.paragraph1: Elinor can be applied as either a field-based assessment with a trained facilitator or as a desk-based tool that harnesses local and practitioner knowledge.
explanation.paragraph2: The questions within Elinor are high-level, covering a broad range of topics and can help stakeholders better understand issues related to the equitable governance and management of areas under protection or management.

trackingChange.title: TRACKING CHANGE
trackingChange.text: Elinor has been designed primarily to help track changes over time, thus can be used at any stage in the project cycle to:
trackingChange.list:
• Indicate the suitability of a site for different types of interventions
  • Highlight areas that require more focused interventions to enhance implementation efforts.
  • Invite stakeholders to collaboratively reflect on a broad range of issues important for area-based conservation

elinor.title: In Honor
elinor.subtitle: Elinor “Lin” Ostrom
elinor.paragraph1: Elinor Ostrom was the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in economics in 2009, but her legacy extends far beyond that singular honor. Ostrom and her colleagues countered the dominant narrative around the tragedy of the commons (which argued that individuals pursue their own interest even when it goes against the collective good—made famous by an ecologist who was a known racist and eugenicist). Ostrom’s theory on governing the commons proved that our planet could be protected through community, collaboration, and cooperation.
elinor.paragraph2: Research on the governance of common pool resource management pushed boundaries of science and challenged the usual divisions between disciplines. Working in true partnership with others who understood the world in different ways, Ostrom and her colleagues paved the way for a new research community and body of knowledge that embraces diversity and the intertwined nature of human and natural systems.
elinor.paragraph3: Ostrom’s legacy shapes how we work today in conservation, and by honoring her in our work, we hope that her insights can help us all better support both the communities and governance systems that protect our natural resources now and into the future.

quote.text: Little by little, bit by bit, family by family, so much good can be done on so many levels.
quote.author: ELINOR OSTROM

faqs.title: FAQs
faqs.text: Just getting started with Elinor or would like to learn more about use cases and common applications? Visit the FAQ section to see these common questions answered.

methodology.title: METHODOLOGY
methodology.text: Learn more about how you can use the Elinor assessment and download the field protocol and assessment tool.
methodology.text2: Elinor includes 35 questions across 10 governance and management attributes. Each question is scored 0-3 and those scores equally contribute to their respective attribute scores. In turn, the attribute scores equally contribute to the overall score. Depending on the given score, Elinor suggests different actions steps, including Plan, Build, Strengthen, and Maintain. It is important to note that although these scores provide important insights, they should be used together with the qualitative data entered into Elinor when deciding what adaptive management actions to take.

spatialFile.title: Upload Map Area File
spatialFile.fileCorrectlyFormatedText: Your file has been successfully verified and is ready for upload
spatialFile.help:
What file to upload?

Upload a zipped shapefile of the boundaries of the managed area. The zip should contain the component files of the shapefile and should only be one shapefile of the boundary. If you do not have the correct file type, please convert first before you upload.
spatialFile.condition1: zip file containing all necessary shapefile files (or a zip with a folder containing those files)
spatialFile.condition3: shapefile only -- including all required sidecar files (.shp, .shx, .dbf, .prj)
spatialFile.condition5: no null, empty, or otherwise invalid geometries

imageFile.title: Upload Map Image File

imageFile.help:
What file to upload?

If you do not have a shapefile but have an image map of the managed area you may upload it here and it will be processed manually.

popup.title: How to create an Assessment
popup.text: Use the process below to create an assessment. You will need to provide information relating to the assessment, create or select a managed area and then complete the actual survey questions. Collaborators functionality enables you to add people to your assessment.

step-1.title: Choose your pathway for data collection
step-1.text: Elinor can be completed in one of two ways:
step-1.li-1: Through a facilitated focus group with different stakeholders involved in and affected by the MA
step-1.li-2: As a desk-based assessment led by for example, a conservation practitioner or a site manager.

step-2.title: Assessment Data
step-2.text: Complete the information related to the ASSESSMENT, such as the number of people consulted or related institutions

step-3.title: Management Area
step-3.text: Identify the Management Area, its belonging to some PA and upload the shape or draw on the map its location.

step-4.title: The survey
step-4.text: Answer the questions from the Survey. You can select those attributes that are relevant to your Assessment

step-5.title: Collaborators
step-5.text: Invite collaborators to help you complete the Assessment, or share only as an observer

step-6.title: Publish
step-6.text: Once the Assessment is complete you can publish it, making it accessible from the public zone of the web

intro.text: Below are documents that are important for full understanding and use of the Elinor tool. Each document has a short description. Please download as required.

methodologyPage.title: Methodology
methodologyPage.paragraph1: The Elinor assessment can be completed in two different ways: Through a facilitated focus group with different stakeholders involved in and affected by the MA, or as a desk-based assessment led by a conservation practitioner. When inputting data, users can indicate which pathway they took to generate the data in the assessment and what types of stakeholders were engaged in the assessment.
methodologyPage.subtitle1: Elinor as a field-based focus group discussion
methodologyPage.paragraph2: Most governance assessments are traditionally completed through participatory focus group discussions; leveraging diverse perceptions from key stakeholders involved in the management and governance of a particular area. For those with the time and capacity to gather diverse perspectives on management and governance, we recommend downloading the Elinor assessment tool and protocol to guide your efforts.
methodologyPage.paragraph3: This guidance offers insights on how to ethically lead a group, obtain the right permissions for using the data, and to probe for diverse perspectives; especially of those who may have been traditionally marginalized. This is the preferred pathway, as it allows diverse voices to contribute to the assessment, providing a more holistic perspective on the status of management and governance in an area.
methodologyPage.subtitle2: Elinor as a practitioner-led, desk-based assessment.
methodologyPage.paragraph4: This pathway is for those who have limited time, resources, or capacities for carrying out a participatory focus group. While a desk-based assessment offers a limited option, it allows for some data to be generated on the managed area, which can provide an often adequate and helpful assessment on the current status and trends in the area, and can help users identify any critical knowledge gaps that would require further research and investment. Should you choose to take this pathway, allocate time for you and your colleagues familiar with the MA to discuss and answer each question, based on your experience and knowledge of the MA. If possible, we recommend engaging different stakeholders in whatever way you can to gain insights on the different questions.
methodologyPage.paragraph5: Following is how assessments are scored.

plan.title: Plan
plan.description: Collaborate with rights holders and other actors to develop plans for addressing severe governance gaps

build.title: Build
build.description: Collaborate with rights holders and other actors to build upon initial progress to address major governance gap

strengthen.title: Strengthen
strengthen.description: Collaborate with rights holders and other actors to strengthen governance by addressing minor gaps

maintain.title: Maintain
maintain.description: Collaborate with rights holders and other actors to maintain strong governance and monitor potential threats

legend.strong: Use the form below to contact us
legend.default: We will respond as soon as possible

collaboration.title: Principles of Collaboration and Citation Guidelines

intro.title: Principles to guide transparent and collaborative data sharing
intro.paragraph1: The Elinor tool and data system helps users track management and governance status over time. It also provides the opportunity for sharing data on management and governance between users, which can in the long term, foster more transparency in management and governance and improve area-based conservation efforts.
intro.paragraph2: To achieve this vision, all users should adhere to the principles outlined below that will guide collaborative, fair, and transparent sharing and use of data. Doing so will ensure all users are motivated to contribute data openly to improve area-based conservation.
intro.paragraph3: Data owners who use the Elinor assessment tool and data system have contributed time and resources into collecting data, and in many cases, choose to make their assessments public. Thus all users should act openly, respectfully, transparently, and honestly in engaging on the platform to guide effective and inclusive collaboration. The principles below are designed to facilitate fair and transparent collaboration between data owners and data users, and offer guidance on how users should engage with private and public data, as well as one another.
intro.paragraph4: Please contact us if you have suggestions on how we can improve our collaborative principles
intro.blockquote: All users should act openly, respectfully, transparently, and honestly in engaging on the platform to guide effective and inclusive collaboration

guidelines1.title: Guiding principles for sharing and using data with Elinor
guidelines1.subtitle: For use of public and private data
guidelines1.answer1: Assessment results are provided with additional supporting metadata, which describes its source, how it was compiled, its quality and any limitations, please make sure this is reflected in how you use and present the data.
guidelines1.question2: Always acknowledge the data owners in any presentation, publication or report, and cite the Elinor data system as the source of information.
guidelines1.answer2-1: We recommend using the following statement when using data from the Elinor platform “We express our gratitude to the individuals and institutions who supported generating data for the Elinor Assessment in [INSERT MA OR REGION HERE], including any focus group participants and facilitators”

answer2-2.paragraph1: Please use the following citation to refer to the Elinor data system:
answer2-2.paragraph2: Elinor: A tool and data system for assessing equitable management and governance for area-based conservation. (YEAR) Available at: elinordata.org [Access Date]

guidelines2.subtitle: Principles to guide the request and use of private data in Elinor
guidelines2.text: Not all data in the Elinor platform is made public, however data users can contact data owners and request that data be shared. Data owners have no obligation to share data, but should they choose to do so, data users should adhere to the following principles:
guidelines2.question1: Always use the information granted by users solely in connection with the original request.
guidelines2.answer1: If your initial request was to use the information in a presentation and you later decide it may be useful in a paper or funding proposal, please make a new request to the user.
guidelines2.question2: Never share the information with any third party without the express permission of the user.
guidelines2.answer2: If you wish to share the information with a third party who you may be collaborating with, please inform the data owner first.
guidelines2.question3: Follow acknowledgement guidelines as suggested by the data owner.

answer3.paragraph1: The data owners have the right to request how they want data to be credited for publication. We suggest using the citation format listed below. We also suggest when possible, authors of reports and publications consider inviting data collectors to co-author publications, given their contributions in collecting data.
answer3.paragraph2: DATA OWNER NAMES (ASSESSMENT YEAR). ASSESSMENT LOCATION. INSTITUTION. Occurrence dataset accessed via Elinordata.org on DATE.

attribute1.name: 1. Resource boundaries
attribute1.description: This attribute measures the quality of MA boundaries. The questions ask whether the boundaries of the MA are i) easily identifiable and ii) known by all relevant stakeholders.
attribute1.useIf: You wish to understand whether the boundaries of the MA are well established.
attribute1.reportText: Measures the extent that boundaries of the MA are clearly marked and understood by key rights holders and other actors

attribute2.name: 2. Monitoring and enforcement
attribute2.description: This attribute measures how well the MA is able to enforce regulations and whether there is a system for monitoring important information on the social and ecological conditions in the MA.It looks specifically at penalties for breaking MA rules and their nature and extent. It also measures whether social, ecological or climate change conditions are monitored.
attribute2.useIf: You would like a preliminary understanding about rule breaking in the MA and whether information exists that may facilitate M&E activities or feed into adaptive management.
attribute2.reportText: Measures how well the MA is able to enforce regulations

attribute3.name: 3. Capacity for adaptive management
attribute3.description: This attribute measures whether decision-makers responsible for managing the MA incorporate different forms of knowledge into their decision-making.
attribute3.useIf: You would like to know what sort of information informs management decisions in the MA.
attribute3.reportText: Measures whether MA managers incorporate different forms of knowledge into their decision-making

attribute4.name: 4. Operational capacity
attribute4.description: This attribute measures whether those responsible for managing the MA have the resources to do so. It specifically looks at staff resources, enforcement capacity, budget and equipment needs.
attribute4.useIf: You wish to assess the capacity of the MA’s management system.
attribute4.reportText: Measures whether those responsible for managing the MA have the resources to do so

attribute5.name: 5. Inclusive and equitable management
attribute5.description: This attribute measures inclusivity and equity in MA management, two important components of good governance.Questions on inclusion and equity ask whether the MA authorities allow for local stakeholders to contribute to management decisions, if there is a strategy for sharing the benefits equitably among stakeholders and whether community resilience to climate change is factored into management.
attribute5.useIf: You wish to understand whether the MA includes vulnerable groups in management decisions and outcomes.
attribute5.reportText: Measures inclusivity and equity in MA managment, particulary regarding vulnerable groups

attribute6.name: 6. Clearly defined rights and decision making
attribute6.description: This attribute measures community rights in natural resource management.Rights are extremely important as they lay the foundation (providing incentives or disincentives) for local community stakeholders to meaningfully engage in managing natural resources and in conservation.
attribute6.useIf: You wish to assess the local communities' control over, or access to, the natural resources in the MA you work.
attribute6.reportText: Measures the extent that community rights in natural resource management are clearly understood by key rights holders and other actors

attribute7.name: 7. Clear and congruent regulations
attribute7.description: This attribute measures the quality of MA regulations.    Specifically i) how clear they are and ii) how well they align with; stakeholder input into MA governance, other levels of management authority and the social and environmental context in which they operate.
attribute7.useIf: You wish to understand whether the regulations are clearly stated and fair.
attribute7.reportText: Measures the extent that MA regulations are clear and align with rights-holders and other actors’ governance goals

attribute8.name: 8. Transparency and accountability
attribute8.description: This attribute measures transparency, accountability and conflict resolution all of which are important to good governance. It is important that people directly impacted by management decisions are informed of them in advance of being implemented, decision makers are held to account and there are opportunities for conflict resolution.Transparency is measured by asking whether the MA authority’s communication of information to local stakeholders is timely, accountability is measured by asking whether the MA authority faces consequences if it does not fulfill its responsibilities and the conflict resolution mechanism is assessed for how effective it is.
attribute8.useIf: If you want to assess the quality of MA governance.
attribute8.reportText: Measures the extent that people directly impacted by management decisions are informed of them in advance, can hold decision-makers to account, and have opportunities for conflict resolution

attribute9.name: 9. Perceived outcomes
attribute9.description: This attribute measures the general perceptions those completing the Elinor assessment have on the social and ecological outcomes of the MA.
attribute9.useIf: You wish to know whether those involved in the MA think its objectives are being achieved.
attribute9.reportText: Measures the general perceptions that those completing the Elinor assessment have on the ecological and social outcomes of the MA

attribute10.name: 10. Perceived social outcomes
attribute10.description: This attribute measures the general perceptions that individuals completing the Elinor assessment have on the social outcomes of the MA.
attribute10.useIf: You wish to know whether individuals involved in the MA believe that its social objectives are being achieved.
attribute10.reportText: Measures the general perceptions that those completing the Elinor assessment have on the social outcomes of the MA.

attribute_use.6: You wish to assess the local communities' control over, or access to, the natural resources in the MA you work.

attribute_use.8: If you want to assess the quality of MA governance.
attribute_use.9: You wish to know whether those involved in the MA think its objectives are being achieved.
attribute_use.10: You wish to know whether those involved in the MA think its social objectives are being achieved.
